subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: NBC English - oh, and Hi everyone
msgSnippet: QuikSkript can be more difficult to read, especially when other people write it and have their unique connections to the letters. Shavian Script is best
messageBody:
QuikSkript can be more difficult to read, especially when other people write it and have their unique connections to the letters. Shavian Script is best printed as it is quite clear. Moreover, the letters cover all the sounds of the English alphabet whereas in QuikSkript there is some fudging. You cannot write as fast in Shavian Script however. I know both scripts but still enjoy reading Shavian Script. It is a matter of taste after all.
Sid

<-----Original Message----->
>
> From: stbett
> Sent: 8/31/2002 8:01:08 AM
> To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: NBC English - oh, and Hi everyone
>
> Hi Grant, welcome to the group.
>
> Issue #1: Shouldn't the base dialect be more neutral?
>
> Just because there is a base dialect does not mean that you have to
> speak that way. It does mean that you have to be familiar with the
> dialect if that is the basis of standardized spelling.
>
> Currently English spelling is based on a dialect that no one speaks,
> some have argued that it is more or less based on Elizabethan
> English.
>
> It will be much easier for all to phonemically spell as an NBC
> commentator speaks than as Queen Elizabeth spoke. I don't think the
> issue is proper pronunciation. It is more a case of a pronunciation
> that will be widely understood.
>
> For non published material people can write other dialects.
>
> Issue #2 I just heard that Read had improved his
> original and so I just skipped straight to Quikscript. But from
> discussions here it would seem that the Shavian community is
> considerably bigger. Does anyone know why? Is it just that it's
> older?
>
> Unlike Shavian, Quickscript received virtually no press. It also
> represents an abandonment of the analytical approach found in the
> Shaw alphabet. Quickscript corrects one typo in Shavian and
> simplifies the orthography. It is an improvement on many dimensions
> but not all.
>
> Regards,
>
> Steve
>
